glossary.item: the main chip in a computer and another name for microprocessor
stored information for the computer to perform its intended function
a peripheral that provides information to the computer
a peripheral that delivers information to the user
the selection and interconnection of hardware components to create computers that meet functional, performance, and cost goals
chips made up of transistors and other components that are connected to perform a given function
carry the electrical current within a computer
an internet browser
the software that runs a computer, tablet, or smartphone
allows users to see what they are doing by using icons, windows, and menus to interact within a computer
ROM: provides information to devices but is not written to by the user
RAM: allows the user to both read and write to this memory to improve the computer's functionality
set of instructions that tells electronic devices how to operate
devices that connect to a computer to provide input or output functions
an organized method of naming and storing files
the main display screen on a computer
letters and numbers
the way data is encoded and stored
the letters after a period in the filename that indicate the file format
the act of finding the problem
the act of fixing the problem
Windows software that analyzes and removes unneeded files
Windows software that organizes files to free up space on the hard drive
software that protects your computer from harmful files by detecting and removing them
a program that is intended to interfere with computer, tablet, or smartphone operations and can be spread from one device to another
program designed to breach the security of a computer, tablet, smartphone, or network
malware that replicates itself in order to spread to other computers, tablets, or smartphones
software that allows others to steal your information
software that automatically displays or downloads advertising material
software intended to damage or take partial control of a computer, tablet, or smartphone
software program or piece of hardware that helps screen out hackers, viruses, and worms that try to reach your computer over the internet
turning your computer off and then back on
a program that monitors the system, provides information about the processes and programs running on a computer, and informs the user about the general status of the computer
an appliance designed to protect electrical devices from voltage spikes
the initial set of operations that a computer system performs after electrical power to the CPU is switched on or when the computer is reset
a network that has a central, powerful computer (called the server) that acts as a hub for other, less powerful computers or devices (called clients) to connect to
a network where computers connect to other computers to share information, not through a main server
a powerful computer that typically has clients connected to it
computers connected to a network
a cable used for high-speed connections
a wireless connection through radio waves that is compatible with wireless networking standards
a wireless connection using short-wave radio frequencies
an internet server that allows for file sharing between those given access to the server
message sent over the internet that appears on the recipient's screen as soon as it is sent
meeting by a group of people over the phone
meeting by a group of people through the use of video and audio
a table of data (text or numbers) arranged in columns and rows
a single Excel spreadsheet that contains cells organized by rows and columns
an Excel file that contains one or more worksheets
a vertical arrangement of items; Excel columns are identified by letters (Column A, B, C, etc.)
a horizontal arrangement of items; Excel rows are identified by numbers (Row 1, 2, 3, etc.)
the rectangular box at the intersection point of a column and row, where data is entered
able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities
words, phrases, or images that can be clicked on to open a new document
the design and arrangement of things so they can be used easily and safely
Cc: stands for “carbon copy,” which is a copy of the original
Bcc: stands for “blind carbon copy,” which means the original recipient cannot see additional recipients of the email
unsolicited and undesired email messages
the arrangement of the parts of a page
the direction of a page where the longer side runs from top to bottom; tall and narrow
the direction of the page where the longer side runs from top to bottom; wide and short
an explanatory note or reference at the bottom of the page, referring to a specific part of the text on the page
an explanatory note or reference on the last page of a document, referring to a specific part of the text on the page
an arrangement of data in rows and columns
the automatic settings preset by the manufacturer
the ability to total a column or row of numbers by selecting the cells you want to sum
the borders, or edges, of the page; the computer defaults to one-inch borders on the left, right, top, and bottom of the page
the position of the page
move the beginning of a line or paragraph further from the margin
parentheses, exponents, multiplication, division, addition, subtraction
cell or range of cells on a worksheet to be calculated in a formula
cell reference in a formula that does not change if the formula is copied and pasted into a new cell or range of cells
cell reference in a formula that changes automatically if the formula is copied and pasted into a new cell or range of cells
Productivity, Accessibility, Collaboration, and Efficiency
a medium is a material (paint, colored pencils, charcoal, clay, etc.) used to create art
a question or a request for information about something
a lecture, demonstration, performance, or speech
a single page of a presentation
a predesigned format ready to be filled in and customized
a one-to-two sentence introduction that grabs the audience's attention
short and sweet, clear and concise, attention-grabbing, and narrative
relating to art, images, and graphic design
relating to audio and video
a visual image used to represent information or data
the process of changing from one form or condition to another
the exclusive legal right, given to an originator or creator, to print, publish, perform, film, or record literary, artistic, or musical material, and to authorize others to do the same
in/out of accordance with the rules or standards for right conduct or practice
belonging or being available to the public as a whole, and therefore not subject to copyright
using or reproducing another's work without permission
the difference between light and dark areas
a standard course of action adopted or proposed by a government, party, business, or individual
the assistance and advice provided by a company to those people who buy or use its products or services
interactions with or between people, particularly in a professional context
how people manage and express themselves
ability to communicate or interact well with other people
oral exchange of information; speaking
exchange of information without speaking; i.e. body language or writing
ability to pay attention to and interpret what other people are saying
the act of working with someone to produce or create something
working with others to find a mutually agreeable outcome
working with others to identify, define, and solve problems
exploring and analyzing options to make sound decisions
all the customers or possible customers for a product or service in all areas of the world
new technologies that will substantially alter the business and social environment
portable computing devices like cell phones, tablets, wearable watches and bands
household appliances that stay connected to the internet via home network or wi-fi connection and can be accessed and controlled remotely from any internet-accessible computer or mobile device.

a network in which objects, animals, or people are provided with unique identifiers and the ability to communicate, sense, and interact over a network without requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction
networked devices that exchange information and perform actions without the manual assistance of humans
radio frequency identification; a technology that uses electronic tags placed on objects, people, or animals to relay identifying information to an electronic reader through radio waves
advice intended to help or improve something, often with an offer of possible solutions
the process of resolving a dispute or disagreement
a situation in which each party benefits in some way
restate another's words using different words
person who has the overall responsibility for successfully planning, executing, and completing a project
estimated amount of money needed to complete a project
the global communication network that allows almost all computers worldwide to connect and exchange information
converting the symbolic arrangement of statements or instructions in a computer program into another symbolic arrangement, usually in an encoded or unreadable form
arranging data for computer input or output, such as the number and size of fields in a record or the spacing and punctuation of information in a report
a software application for retrieving, presenting, and navigating information resources on the World Wide Web
a language, software application, or hardware device that works on more than one system platform
a company that provides internet access
the physical items in a device that are needed to access the internet
a part of the internet made up of a virtual network of websites connected by hyperlinks
Uniform Resource Locator: the global address of documents and other resources on the internet
the language computers use to communicate over the internet
program that translates domain names to IP addresses
the extension that defines how a web browser displays the elements (text, images, links, and video) on a web page
a unique name that identifies a website
the unique 32-bit number assigned to every machine on the internet
HyperText Markup Language: the authoring language developed to create web pages; it defines the structure and layout of a web document
a group of computer systems and other computing hardware devices linked together to enable communication and resource-sharing among a wide range of users
a private local network accessible only to an organization's staff
an intranet that is partially accessible to authorized people outside the business or organization
limitations imposed on the activities of an organization in compliance with the organization's regulations
a style of interaction that uses windows, icons, menus, and pointer
a separate viewing area on a computer monitor
a style of interaction that uses a finger or stylus
arrange or order a computer system, or an element of it, so as to fit it to a designated task
a software system designed to search for information on the World Wide Web
a program in which all or some parts of the software are downloaded from the web each time it is run on the browser or mobile device
websites and applications used by large groups of people to share information and to develop social and professional contacts
a regularly updated website that is typically written by a person or small group in an informal, conversational tone and allows readers to comment
computer application that allows users to work together, even when working remotely
an application that distributes messages to subscribers on an electronic mailing list
website suffixes like .com, .edu, .gov, .mil, and .org
intended to make a profit
an organization whose purpose is to benefit the general public, not to make money
the activity of getting information about a subject
related to formal study or research
frequently asked questions
resource that teaches someone how to do something by explaining each stage of a process
online discussion board hosted by a business, organization, or person that allows users to discuss the product or service
capable of being believed
to solve problems or correct errors
the specific number range assigned to any text, indicating its reading difficulty in terms of its semantics (vocabulary) and syntax (sentence length and word order)
the ability to read text and understand its meaning
a web page set as the default or start-up page on a browser
a shortcut to a previously viewed website stored in your browser
user-specified settings
Post Office Protocol 3 (POP3), Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP), or Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP)
small files that websites put on your PC to store information about you and your preferences
a window that appears suddenly on a computer screen often for advertising
a person who uses computers to gain unauthorized access to a computer's data
a file format that provides an electronic image of a document and can be viewed, printed, and electronically transmitted
universal file format that can include information such as text style, size, and color and can be read by all word processors
messages that communicate commands to the computer
single, usually hypertext document on the World Wide Web that can incorporate text, graphics, sounds, etc.
a network consisting of multiple LANs but smaller than a WAN; typically seen in universities and office buildings
a computer network limited to a small area such as an office building, university, or a home
a network covering an area (a city) that is larger than a LAN but smaller than a WAN; typically owned and managed by a single entity
a network that provides access to data storage, so that storage devices can communicate with computers and other devices
a high performing network that connects computer clusters
a network that covers a broad area (like across metropolitan, regional, or national boundaries) using private or public networks
a LAN that is used on wireless technology
a system of rules that defines how internet resources get communicated on a network
the computer or other network device where the resource is located
the path to a particular network resource on the host
a code in a document that specifies how the web page should be formatted
additional information used to modify an element; attributes appear inside the opening tag, and their content sits inside quotation marks
everything from the opening tag to the closing tag, including the content in between the tags
the first tag in a pair of tags is the start (or opening) tag
the second pair in a pair of tags is the end (or closing) tag. It must begin with a forward slash like this: </ >.
instruction to the web browser about what version of HTML the page is written in
the different ways text can appear (i.e. modify text color, size, boldness, italics, and emphasis)
a computer program that allows you to create and edit files that contain plain text
a philosophy regarding the mixing of colors and specific combinations of colors
a circle with different colored sections used to show the relationship between colors
red, yellow, and blue, which are used to create all other colors on the color wheel
orange, green, and purple; these colors are created by mixing equal parts of any two primary colors
red-purple, red-orange, blue-green, yellow-green, blue-purple, and yellow-orange; these are created by mixing equal parts of a secondary and primary color together
a principle that deals with the emotion of the design based on the colors involved and their intensity
an arrangement or combination of colors
a design principle that focuses on how we see colors in relation to other colors that are present in the same work
colors that are opposite each other on the color wheel
three colors that are evenly spaced around the color wheel, making a triangle shape
four colors that are spaced evenly around the color circle, making a square shape
colors that are next to each other on the color wheel
colors that are used sparingly for emphasis
the size and style of the text characters
the arrangement or pattern of elements in a work of art, web page, room, outfit, etc.
a sketch detailing where text and images will be placed on a website
the arrangement of content
a plan that depicts the sequence of the key content
the subjects or topics expressed in writing, images, video, hyperlink, etc.
a picture that is produced by a camera, artist, mirror, etc.
drawings, diagrams, graphs, mathematical curves, symbols, etc.
convert (pictures or sound) into a digital form that can be processed by a computer
service that allows individuals to upload and share images online
professional photographs of common places, landmarks, nature, events or people that are bought and sold on a royalty-free basis and can be used and reused for commercial design purposes
pre-made, copyright-free illustrations used to represent many different topics
a device that is capable of copying a graphic, document, or other object
an external cable and connector used for connecting peripheral devices to a computer
refers to the right to use copyrighted material or intellectual property without the need to pay royalties or license fees
an editor or program that allows a developer to see what the end result will look like while the interface or document is being created
a stylesheet language used to describe how elements of HTML should be displayed onscreen
a stylesheet language used to describe how elements of HTML should be displayed onscreen
popular web programming language; it is widely used to add functionality and interactivity to web pages; Note: It differs from Java
an open source scripting language executed on the server that is free to download
code written as standalone lines known as queries, often used to create, read, update, or delete data in a database
specific, teachable abilities (i.e. reading, solving equations, and using software, etc.) that can be defined and measured
character traits and interpersonal skills that characterize a person's relationships with other people
the reflection of people's typical patterns of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
the supply of available workers in relation to available work
a general direction in which something is developing or changing
the possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring
an occupation performed for a significant period of a person's life and with opportunities for progress
the study or use of systems (especially computers and telecommunications) for storing, retrieving, and sending information
the wealth and resources of a country or region, especially in terms of the production and consumption of goods and services
the future of someone or something
a form used in making a request
a short document describing your education, work history, skills, etc. that you give an employer when applying for a job
a letter that is sent with something to explain the reason for it or to give more information about it
a word or concept of great significance
a formal meeting, usually to evaluate qualifications (as of a prospective student or employee)
a person with senior managerial responsibility in a business organization
in web design, the page title is displayed in the title bar at the top of the browser, and it gives both humans and search engines a quick indication of the contents of the page by using keywords
items used to help explore career options and find career information
the advancement of skills or expertise to succeed in a particular profession through continued education and facilitated learning opportunities
an experienced and trusted adviser
interacting with other people to exchange information and develop contacts, especially to further one's career
a group of people organized for a joint purpose
a person who is advised, trained, or counseled by a mentor
to briefly restate the main points
using an author's language word-for-word with quotation marks
